channel.title: NYT > U.S. News

item.title: Trump Holds 2-Hour Meeting With Noem Amid Backlash to Minneapolis Shooting
item.description: The meeting is a sign that the president is concerned about the fallout from the killing of Alex Pretti, who was shot by immigration agents.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager and Hamed Aleaziz
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Kristi Noem, the homeland security secretary, at the White House earlier this month.

item.title: Chris Madel Ends Run for Minnesota Governor, Citing Immigration Crackdown
item.description: Chris Madel, a defense lawyer, called the operation “simply a disaster.” His decision comes two days after a second fatal shooting by federal agents in Minneapolis.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño and Pooja Salhotra
item.media:credit: Leila Navidi/Star Tribune, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Chris Madel said the immigration crackdown in Minneapolis “has departed so far from the stated goals that it is simply a disaster.”

item.title: Trump Administration Takes Another Stake in Rare Earth Sector
item.description: The administration announced a $1.6 billion deal with USA Rare Earth. The firm also does business with Cantor Fitzgerald, which is run by the sons of President Trump’s commerce secretary.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Liam Kennedy for The New York Times
item.media:description: “This investment ensures our supply chains are resilient and no longer reliant on foreign nations,” Howard Lutnick, the secretary of commerce, said of the deal.

item.title: Trump Briefed on Intelligence Saying Iran’s Government Is Weaker
item.description: Protests that erupted late last year shook elements of the Iranian government, according to the reports.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager, Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Vahid Salemi/Associated Press
item.media:description: A street in Tehran on Sunday. The reports signal that the Iranian government’s hold on power is at its weakest point since the shah was overthrown in the 1979 revolution.

item.title: Alex Pretti Shooting Poses a Question for the Right: Who’s a Conservative?
item.description: Republicans wrestle with Trump administration positions that seem to contradict their beliefs on gun rights, states’ rights and limited use of federal power.
item.dc:creator: Richard Fausset
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
item.media:description: Mourners at the spot where Alex Pretti was killed by federal agents. Protesters have called for immigration agents to leave.

item.title: F.A.A. Rolls Out Agency Overhaul for Improving Air Safety
item.description: The announcement of a reorganization comes nearly a year after a midair collision killed 67 people and prompted a public outcry for enhancing the security of aviation travel.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bryan Bedford, the leader of the Federal Aviation Administration, during a hearing at the Capitol last month.

item.title: A Year After DC Plane Crash, Concerns About Airport’s Safety Continue
item.description: The Federal Aviation Administration says it has reduced traffic in and out of the airport and designed safer routes. Crash victims’ families want more.
item.dc:creator: Kate Kelly
item.media:credit: Kent Nishimura for The New York Times

item.title: What Minneapolis Means for the Country and Its Politics
item.description: Our reporter who spent time in the city weighed in on how the chaos is changing the political landscape.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial in Minneapolis for Alex Pretti, the man killed by federal agents.

item.title: U.S. Investigation Into Minneapolis Shooting of Alex Pretti Appears Limited
item.description: A use-of-force review is far different than a criminal investigation of the killing of Alex Pretti by Border Patrol agents in Minneapolis.
item.dc:creator: Devlin Barrett, Alan Feuer and Hamed Aleaziz
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: People gathering Monday in Minneapolis at a memorial for Alex Pretti.

item.title: Border Patrol Official Gregory Bovino Is Set to Leave Minnesota
item.description: The news of Mr. Bovino’s impending departure came hours after President Trump sent his border czar, Tom Homan, to take control of ICE operations in the state.
item.dc:creator: Hamed Aleaziz
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: U.S. Border Patrol official Gregory Bovino and other U.S. Border Patrol agents earlier this month in Minneapolis, Minnesota.

item.title: The G.O.P. tees up its spending package in Congress, leading to a shutdown showdown.
item.description: Days before a spending deadline, Republicans rejected a demand by Democrats to drop money for the Department of Homeland Security from a government funding package.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Susan Collins, Republican of Maine, and chairwoman of the Appropriations Committee, speaks to reporters, at the U.S. Capitol earlier this month.

item.title: Killings in Minneapolis Invert Usual Dynamic Over Policing the Police
item.description: It is far rarer and more difficult for state authorities to try to investigate federal law enforcement officials than the other way around.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in Minneapolis gather near where Alex Pretti was killed. It is rare for state and local police to try to investigate federal law enforcement officials.

item.title: Alex Pretti Shooting in Minneapolis Went Wrong From the Start, Experts Say
item.description: Law enforcement experts say federal agents deviated from standard practice before and during the shooting of Alex Pretti in Minneapolis, based on videos.
item.dc:creator: Reis Thebault and Maia Coleman
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
item.media:description: In the moments leading up to the shooting of Alex Pretti in Minneapolis, federal agents had acted in ways that raised serious questions among policing experts.

item.title: Democrats Embrace a Shutdown Fight They Wanted to Avoid
item.description: After a second fatal shooting of a U.S. citizen in Minneapolis, Democrats say public opinion is on their side and they are willing to risk a backlash to counter what they see as police-state tactics.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal agents in Minneapolis after the shooting of a U.S. citizen on Saturday.

item.title: Under Biden Administration, Justice Dept. Began Examining Ilhan Omar’s Finances
item.description: The inquiry, initiated by the U.S. attorney’s office in Washington, appears to have stalled for lack of evidence.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush and Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Ilhan Omar at the Capitol this month. The investigation into her finances was thrust into the public spotlight on Monday, when President Trump posted about it on Truth Social.

item.title: Takeaways From Minnesota Hearing Over ICE Surge
item.description: Judge Kate M. Menendez did not say when she might rule on the state of Minnesota’s request for an order halting the surge of immigration enforcement.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
item.media:description: Tense confrontations have played out between federal agents and people on the streets of Minneapolis.

item.title: On Venezuela and Greenland, Many Trump Fans Give Him the Benefit of the Doubt
item.description: At least so far, President Trump has managed to bring along even those conservative supporters who are skeptical of foreign interventions.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Loren Elliott for The New York Times
item.media:description: A meeting of the Turning Point USA chapter last week at the University of Idaho in Moscow, Idaho.

item.title: Democrats Who Voted to Fund ICE Distance Themselves From DHS
item.description: A small group of Democrats who supported a spending bill for the Department of Homeland Security were on the defensive after the fatal shooting by a federal agent in Minneapolis.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Tom Suozzi, Democrat of New York, confronts January 6th supporters in Washington earlier this month.

item.title: White House Distances Trump From Initial Response to Minnesota Killing
item.description: The departure of Gregory Bovino, whose tactics have drawn sharp criticism, is an indication that officials see Alex Pretti’s killing as a political threat to President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater and David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: “This has obviously been a very fluid and fast-moving situation throughout the weekend,” Karoline Leavitt, the White House press secretary, said on Monday.

item.title: Justice Dept. Drops Charges of Assault of an Officer in Minnesota
item.description: It appeared to be the first time that the department has backed away from pursuing a case of an assault against a federal agent in Minnesota since the administration ramped up an immigration crackdown.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators at the Bishop Henry Whipple Federal Building in Minneapolis earlier this month. Federal prosecutors dropped assault charges on Monday against a man accused of ramming his vehicle into federal agents.

item.title: Why Is the Trump Administration Demanding Minnesota’s Voter Rolls?
item.description: The Justice Department has urged Minnesota to hand over voters’ private data. It is part of a national push that has raised concerns about the Trump administration’s motives.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Attorney General Pam Bondi has pushed Minnesota to turn over its full voter roll.

item.title: ICE Protesters Enter Minneapolis Hotel Vestibule, Setting Off a Fracas
item.description: The Minneapolis police said federal agents arrived and used gas on a crowd, refusing further assistance.
item.dc:creator: Talya Minsberg and Jamie Kelter Davis
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Armed U.S. Border Patrol agents guarded the lobby and common areas of the Home2Suites hotel on Sunday night after dispersing protesters.

item.title: Minneapolis Carries On, but Shootings and ICE Clashes Keep Residents on Edge
item.description: “I’m a 48-year-old white guy, and I don’t feel really safe,” one resident said about the continuing federal law enforcement tactics in the city.
item.dc:creator: Chris Hippensteel and Bernard Mokam
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hockey on Lake of the Isles in Minneapolis on Sunday.

item.title: Minnesota Refugees Detained by ICE ‘Had Done Everything Right’
item.description: Dozens of refugees with valid status have been sent from Minnesota to Texas to be revetted, prompting a lawsuit. Those released have had to pay their way back.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan and Hamed Aleaziz
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
item.media:description: More than 100 refugees with no criminal record from about a dozen countries have been detained in Minnesota by agents in recent weeks.

item.title: Nigella Lawson Joins ‘The Great British Baking Show’ as a Judge
item.description: Ms. Lawson, 66, replaces Prue Leith, who announced her departure this month.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser
item.media:credit: Anna Kucera/The Sydney Morning Herald, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Nigella Lawson in 2018. Her 1998 cookbook “How to Eat” helped make her a star in the culinary world.

item.title: Trump Is Sending Tom Homan, His Border Czar, to Minnesota
item.description: “He has not been involved in that area, but knows and likes many of the people there,” President Trump wrote on Truth Social on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Hamed Aleaziz
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Tom Homan outside the White House this month.

item.title: The ‘R-Word’ Returns, Dismaying Those Who Fought to Oust It
item.description: The term, long considered a slur for those with intellectual disabilities, is seeing a resurgence on social media and across the political right.
item.dc:creator: Dan Barry and Sonia A. Rao
item.media:credit: Kathleen Flynn for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jill Eglé, a disability advocate who was a driving force in having the “R- word” eliminated at the state level in Virginia.

item.title: Our Photographer Describes the Scene After the Pretti Shooting
item.description: David Guttenfelder, a Times photographer based in Minneapolis, describes what he saw at the scene where Alex Jeffrey Pretti had been killed by federal agents.
item.dc:creator: David Guttenfelder, Sutton Raphael, Christina Shaman, Coleman Lowndes, Thomas Vollkommer and Nikolay Nikolov

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.dc:creator: Hamed Aleaziz, Ernesto Londoño, David E. Sanger and Mitch Smith

item.title: A Crisis of Confidence for ICE and Border Patrol as Clashes Escalate
item.description: Current and former officials describe growing frustration and disillusionment with the Trump administration’s approach, even as they support the goal of immigration enforcement.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Nehamas, Hamed Aleaziz, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Alexandra Berzon
item.media:credit: Ivan Pierre Aguirre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oscar Hagelsieb, a former resident agent in charge with Homeland Security Investigations, in El Paso on Sunday.

item.title: Federal Court Will Hear Minnesota Claims That Immigration Surge is Illegal
item.description: State and local officials say the federal deployment of immigration agents violates the 10th Amendment. The surge, which the Trump administration has defended, has led to three shootings and tense protests.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal agents confronted people in Minneapolis on Saturday.

item.title: Voters See a Middle-Class Lifestyle as Drifting Out of Reach, Poll Finds
item.description: Concerns about the affordability of education, housing, health care, having a family and retirement are driving economic anxieties, a New York Times/Siena poll found.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer, Ruth Igielnik and Camille Baker
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Trump Hobbled the I.R.S. This C.E.O. Now Has to Make It Work.
item.description: Frank Bisignano is the first chief executive of the I.R.S., where there’s hope he will end a chaotic stretch at the agency. The tax filing season, which started Monday, is his first test.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Duehren
item.media:credit: Eric Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: This year’s tax filing season could be an even more formidable challenge than usual for the Internal Revenue Service and Frank Bisignano, its chief executive.

item.title: In Memphis, Federal Crime Task Force Keeps Residents on Edge
item.description: Support from Republican state leaders for the crime-fighting operation — and to an extent, from the city’s Democratic mayor — has kept tensions to an uneasy simmer.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.category: Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives
item.media:credit: Brad J. Vest for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cars are often stopped on the side of the road in Memphis, surrounded by clusters of law enforcement agents and a mix of patrol and unmarked cars.

item.title: How Bad Are A.I. Delusions? We Asked People Treating Them.
item.description: Dozens of doctors and therapists said chatbots had led their patients to psychosis, isolation and unhealthy habits.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Valentino-DeVries and Kashmir Hill
item.media:credit: William DeShazer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Julia Sheffield, a psychologist at Vanderbilt University Medical Center in Nashville, is navigating how to treat problems caused or exacerbated by A.I. chatbots.

item.title: Ice Storm Leaves Thousands Without Power in a Mississippi County
item.description: More than 20,000 households had no power late Sunday in Lafayette County, a day after freezing rain hit the Oxford area.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri and Max Kim
item.media:credit: USA Today Network, via Reuters
item.media:description: A damaged pole in Oxford, Miss., on Sunday.
